30711975.review:
Quick Port Overview for those looking to buy:

[*] Playable with Keyboard and Mouse, seems responsive

[*] Detailed resolution options only in fullscreen, more limited in Windowed (544p, 720p, 1080p on my 1080p-Monitor). But you can change to a custom resolution via the launcher.ini at
My Documents/My Games/Zero Escape The Nonary Games

[*] Borderless Windowed Option

[*] Simple graphic options menu, includes AA up to 16x and AF

[*] Audio output seems bugged, my headset is the output, which is connected to a PCIe-Soundcard, deactivitating via Windows doesn't work. Workaround is to plug the speakers to the sound card, could be fixed in a patch as far as I can see

[*] On my RX 480/i5 6600k Desktop 999 runs perfectly smooth and fine without dips. It was the same at first on my i5 2520M T420s, but for some reason it started to dip to 17 - 22 FPS within the second riddle. I turned off AA and AF and it's running without the severe frame tanking. Also, I can't see any difference in graphic fidelity with having those turned off. So I guess it's a must-have option to turn off AA and AF if you have a lower end system.

[*] The UI does not scale at all as it seems, the Save Screen is huge and is convoluted, will update when getting further into the game

[*] Menu options don't scroll with mouse wheel or with the movement of your mouse, only a click or using the arrow keys will change the highlighted menu button

[*] There are keyboard shortcuts for the various interactions in the game, but are not rebindable. It's also completely playable only using the mouse so far.

[*] It has only 30 save files, though that is more than enough for someone like me.

[*] The game has native Steam Controller and Dualshock 4 support with the default profiles (thanks to Moskeeto)

[*] 999 and VLR don't have a "Close"-button, but you can quit out of the game via Right Click in the Main Menu or via the B-Button on XBOX (or equivalent) controller

[*] I forgot to note that both Virtues Last Reward and 999 have a options menu, where you can adjust seperate audio sliders like BGM, SFX and Voices. You also have a sensitivity choice for the cursor (if using a Gamepad is something you'd want to do), as well as a option to enable skip text and a choice between Japanese and English voices. I am using the Japanese voiceover and so far, besides the puzzle bits, it seems to be fully voiced with animations.

[*] You can change between GamePad and Keyboard/Mouse on the fly, the only thing that the launcher option for the input device changes seems to be the shown input button ingame

[*] Game speed seems to be tied to framerate, so thats unfortunate.

It seems alright besides the Audio issue. Might want to wait for one or two patches.

39401725.review:
[this is a review of 999; I have not played VLR yet]
I'm not a fan of anime. Not of the art style, not of the peculiarities of storytelling, and I'm very far from a Japanophile in terms of culture. Thus, as you may guess, I approached this game with some hesitation. 
But a good friend recommended it, and so I decided to try it. And of course the japanese animation traits that annoy me are here - ridiculous outfits, ridiculous character designs (how am I supposed to guess this sexy looking chick is around 18 years' old and the other one is at least 40? they look the same! and this guy looks old-ish - but no, he is also 20-something), exasperatingly awkward flirting and people make a huge deal out of things like "a girl being in the same elevator as a guy", ugh. 
But the plot and the gameplay are so good that I was quite willing to overlook them. The puzzles are nice - require some thinking, but everything is solvable without a walkthrough. The secrets within secrets are delectable, and while the game will explain everything if you finish, it's extremely satisfying to figure out plot points for yourself. Delightfully, the game allows it and gives you just enough clues to feel smart. The voice acting is acceptable, and the way player is allowed to skip over parts they have played through when discovering all possible endings is wonderfully made and meshes perfectly with the game. All in all, this is a brilliant adventure game.

39373589.review:
There was a lot I had issues with when it came to the writing of the game like how a lot of the characters felt completely off besides maybe one or two of them but I really did enjoy this game. Much like how Danganronpa is based around surviving a killing game, this offers a much more complicated path of beating the killing game and saving all the participants you can. The game focuses on puzzle/escape rooms that you need to solve in order to leave the room and progress the story. In each game, there are multiple escape rooms with different kind of puzzles.

All in all, it's a fun mystery and puzzle game that adds a lot of personality thanks to some characters and the problems they face in and out of the killing game.

39273097.review:
Honestly I can talk about The Nonary Games for several hours and I'm not sure if I can adequately sum up my feelings for this game (or rather, [i]these games[/i]), since I experienced so many different emotions during my playthroughs. On top of that, I already played both titles (999 and VLR) on the DS with a friend, though that was years ago.

Generally speaking, I really enjoyed the game. I've always liked 'escape the room' type of games, and a good story, so it was  relatively easy to immerse myself into the game. I definitely found myself becoming attached to the characters and their stories, and there were definitely some moments that were just gut-wrenching.

Out of the two, I would say 999 (the first of the series) was definitely my favourite. It was also much faster to complete. (I spent roughly 29.6 hours on 999, including times when I got up from the computer without closing the game). On the other hand, Virtue's Last Reward (VLR) had a much more detailed story imo and took significantly longer. (I ended somewhere around 40 hours or so).

If you're like me, and you work things out easier on paper, having a notebook nearby is very handy for this type of game. (I wrote a lot of notes....) But! I found that writing the puzzles down didn't detract from the gameplay, and made it easier to remember things! [spoiler]Especially when you needed to decode the message in the infirmary using the 25-digit key in VLR[/spoiler].

But enough about [i]how I played the game...[/i]

[b]PROS[/b]
-The game is very engaging, and hardly becomes dull. The characters have interesting stories about "facts" or "experiments" that are truly fascinating, even if they're made up for the sake of the story. I mean, it is a visual novel after all, so it makes sense that it tells such an incredible story.
-For the most part, all of the puzzles are different. There's always a different challenge behind each door that you choose, and it's just so interesting to work through them as well. 
-The characters feel more "human" than fictional - I swear. The characters in both 999 and VLR felt like they had so much more depth than most fictitious characters that you see nowadays. As I said earlier, it's too easy to grow attached to them.
-The flowchart is a life-saver. I'm not to sure if this mechanic is popular in other visual novels, but not having to [i]restart the entire game in order to achieve a different ending[/i] is just something I appreciate so much. Without it, it probably would have taken me much, much, much longer to finish the game.

[b]CONS[/b]
-The control differences between 999 and VLR. (I was using a controller, for reference). They're not too major, honestly, and this might just be me nitpicking but it took me forever to get used to the differences in VLR. I found that the cursor moved much slower and that it wasn't as accurate. I often opted to use the mouse when inputting passwords, something that I didn't do in 999.
-Some of the endings in 999 were complicated to achieve. Now, this is hardly an issue but there was a specific ending that I needed to complete and I just couldn't figure out how. It just wasn't obvious! So, I guess in short, there may be a lot of Googling with this game if you're like me and don't look at absolutely everything.
-Honestly I found VLR far too long. It became a task closer to the end, trying to get essentially the "true ending" so to speak. [spoiler]Having to jump back and forth between several different timelines just to have the right information to clear the locks was honestly the most tedious thing about the game.[/spoiler]
-My achievement for getting all the trophies didn't show up for over half an hour and honestly I'm still unjustly frustrated about that.

tl;dr I highly recommend it to anyone who lieks visual novels, escape the room, or (hopefully) both!!! Just a fair warning that some puzzles are much more difficult than others and that you may need to look at things several times before getting all the pieces you need.

39267860.review:
Probably one of the best visual novel type games I've ever played. Several interesting concepts and mechanics blended with an intelligent story and decent voice acting. The only thing that I absolutely hate about 999 so far (Haven't played VLR yet) is the writing, specifically the dialogue between characters. The game seems to be pretty mature, so I'm not sure why it treats the audience like they're children. Characters constantly repeat the same exact thing that your character said a few seconds earlier in 5 different ways like they don't expect the player to remember even the most basic details. It's so annoying and so frequent that I have to actually skip dialogue for some scenes. For example:

You: "Wow, would you look at that stick over there!"
Person 1: "That stick over there sure is interesting"
Person 2: "There's a stick over there? Woah!"
You: "The directions say to throw the stick into the water and we'll summon a zombie shark."
Person 1: "So what you're saying is, if we toss the stick over there into the water..."
Person 2: "A SHARK will show up!?"
You: "Let's do it!"
Person 1: "Alright!"
Person 2: "Ok!"

Like seriously, if I wanted to be treated like a mentally disabled toddler with the attention span of a fly I would watch sesame street or listen to some Snake dialogue from MGS3. What's almost as bad is when you figure out something plot related from an obvious clue, and then you have to wait an agonizing three scenes while your character thinks to himself like a mumbling idiot, using all of his peanut brain to figure out what he just saw. Currently the only thing that really bugs me about that game, but overall its a really great experience.

脱出するための重要な鍵となる腕輪を脱落者から回収しようともしない主人公とその他の面々、
ある人に一目見ればわかるほどの特殊な身体的特徴があることを教えてもらった直後だというのに
その後発見された遺体がその人本人なのかどうか確認しない、気がつかない異常な主人公。

典型的な"登場人物を無能にして強引にトリックを成立させる"退屈なゲームでした

-追記-
9時間9人9の扉は次作"善人シボウデス"のプロローグ、いわゆるこの世界のシステム(ルール)説明のための作品で、
善人シボウデスの方ではそのシステムを利用した面白いストーリー展開がありました。

ご都合主義で進む9時間9人9の扉に対する評価は変わりませんが
退屈で分厚い説明書を読んだあとに善人シボウデスをプレイする作品と考えると
貴重な時間をこのゲームに割く価値は十分にあります。

"過去の選択肢が未来の結果に影響する"ノベルゲームは沢山ありますが、
"未来の選択肢が過去に影響する"タイプのノベルゲームは希少ですので
ノベルゲーム好きの方はぜひ善人シボウデスまでプレイを進めてみることをお薦めします。

-補足-
ダンガンロンパ2は好きだけれども1は嫌いだ、という方がもしおられれば
9時間9人9の扉と善人シボウデスも同じような関連性の作品だといえば分かりやすいでしょう。

39442080.review:
I will only recommend this game to a very specific group of people who:
[list] 
[*]Desperately want to have their time wasted and have no problem dealing with the morning-after regret.
[*]Have an inhuman level of tolerance for verbose and childish writing.
[*]Believe in pseudoscience and don’t even bother to look up the legitimacy of it.
[*]Are easily persuaded and believe whatever bull**** people throw at you.
[*]Can turn a blind eye to any ridiculous plot hole and deus ex machina scenario as long as the story moves forward.
[*]Don’t mind their elaborative faculty being questioned and taunted by the devs again and again.
[/list] 
If you find yourself fit in at least four(4) of the categories above, go give it a try, you may have an incredibly fun time with this game. Otherwise you may just end up like me, tortured by regret and fury for all the wasted time and anticipation.
 
I know, Japanese visual novels (also Japanese literature in general) are well known for verbose writing, I had this in mind before stepping into this game.  However, its excessive verboseness still overwhelmed me somehow. You might think I am exaggerating and overacting at this point, so, to sufficiently prove my points, I am going to give a demonstration of two techniques used in this game, two techniques that stretched this game from a story that could have been properly told in 5 hours into an endless marathon.



[h1]Technique 1:[/h1]
I don’t know if this game is made for kids or not, but considering it is rated M in many countries, my suspicion might be incorrect. Anyway, the devs seem to have highly underestimated the elaborative faculty of the players to an almost offensive degree. 

As if describing a fact or ratiocination that sticks out a mile by the narrator wasn’t enough, they just have to recapitulate the same thing (indeed, the exactly same thing, no Rashomon effect involved) through the mouth of every character available at the scene again and again, and eventually, to have the protagonist to sum it up one extra time…

Here is an example:
[b](Note that it’s not an excerpt of any actual in-game scene, but a simplified demonstration of how this “technique” works, as is the example in the next part)[/b]


[quote=Example 1] 
You rushed to the door only to found its handle missing. 
Where the handle was supposed to be, left only an empty socket behind.
You tried to force it open *BAM* *BAM* of no avail.
People gathered around to investigate it. [b](“narrator describes the situation” Check ✓)[/b]

Character 1: “What are you doing? Let’s open this door and proceed!”
You: “I just arrived and found its handle missing.”
Character 2: “A door can only be opened by rotating its handle, I guess we cannot open the door then.” 
Character 3: ”Let me handle this, I’m full of muscle! *BANG* *BANG*”
You: “I tried, it didn’t even budge.”
Character 5: “Let me give you a hand!”
Character 3: “Rawr… Doesn’t work!”
Character 6: “We can’t open the door normally, nor force it open. I figure this door is off-limits to us.”
Character 2: “That’s what I’m thinking, we cannot open this door at this moment.”
Character 4: “Then we are trapped! This is the only door we haven’t entered!”
You: “Maybe there is some other ways to open a door?”
Character 6: “Like teleporting through?” 
Character 4: “How is that possible!?”
Character 2: “How about lockpicking?”
Character 1: “Without a handle, there isn’t any lock to lockpick I’m afraid.”
Character 4: “So we are trapped! We are going to starve to death!”
You: “Is it possible to find some explosives to breach it?” 
Character 2: “Whew! Yes, we can plant some explosives to breach it through. Why haven’t I figured that out.” 
Character 6: “Indeed, it’s a tough door no doubt, but I don’t think it can stand against explosion.”
Character 3: “Good idea! I know I can count on you.”
You: “Is that truly the only way?”
Character 1: “Or we can find the missing handle to fix the door, and open it the way a normal door would.”
Character 5: “Exactly what I was thinking. We can also try finding the missing handle.”
Character 4: “Does that mean we don’t have to die here if we can find the missing handle or get some explosives to breach it?” [b](“every character recaps the same thing at least once” Check ✓)[/b]
You: “So our current objective is clear, we either find the missing handle of the door, or get our hands on some explosives to breach it open. Everybody clear?” [b](“protagonist sums it up one extra time” Check ✓)[/b]
 [/quote]

Did you get how painfully annoying it is?
Also note that since every line is accompanied by dubs and character animations, any simple scenario like this one could easily last ages.



[h1]Technique 2:[/h1]
As you might have already known, the game is consisted of two parts. One is the “
Visual Novel” part, in which you simply read the story, and sometimes make decisions to push the story forward. The other one is the “Room Escape” part, which plays just like any other room escape game, except for the puzzles being mind-numbingly easy and straightforward.

What truly bothers me is that every character keeps saying sh*t that are either too intelligent and informative, or embarrassingly flirty (both from male and female), which is totally out the realm of their character personas and the overall atmosphere. There is one scene where they were just screaming and vomiting after the discovery of a bloody dismembered body, the next minute, they started flirting and recollecting childhood memories right beside the corpse!?

And that isn’t even the worst part, the worst part is that every character keeps commentating before/during/after your every single action! It might be hard to understand how, so here comes the demonstration. 

Imagining yourself entering  a room with two other characters, the room is completely empty except for a tea table in the center and a key atop it. The exit is on the opposite of the room, locked. The solution here is quite self-evident, you grab the key, unlock the door and get out, not much to talk about really. However, such simple scenario would evolve like this in this game:

[quote=Example 2] 
(Just when you enter the room, game freezes.)
Character 2: “Oh, this room is so empty, can we just chill out here for a while and take a break?”
You: “Time is running out, I’m afraid we can’t afford the luxury.”
Character 1: “Yeah, let’s find out the solution to this room.”
Character 2: “You men are always this rushy.”


(Game resumes control, you start to explore the room)


(Just before you are about to grab the key)
Character 2: “Look! There is a key on the table.”
Character 1: “Yeah, I saw that too, I wonder what it opens.”
You: “Let’s take a closer look.”

(Right after you pick up the key)
Character 1: “Hey, what’s that you’re holding? A key?”
You: “Yes, I just found it lying on the table.”
Character 2: “Oh, it looks so stiff and hard.”
You: “Wait, can you say that again?”
Character 2: “Say what again?”
You: “The one you used to describe the key.”
Character 2: “Oh that’s awkward, please forget about it!” 
[b](“ridiculously unnecessary flirting” Check ✓)[/b]

(While you attempt to further search the room)
Character 1:  “Since there are only two doors in this room, one is the one we just entered, the other one must be the exit, why don’t we check it out.”
Character 2: “It looks locked though, but maybe you can unlock it with the key you just found?”
You: “Only one way to find out.”

(When you approach the door.)
Character 1: “Oh, this door is so strongly fortified, there’s no way we can force it open, got to use a key.”

(After you insert the key and open the door.) 
Character 1: “Man, you are such a talented door-opener, I love the way you insert the key into the lockhole, how fierce.”
Character 2: “You guys are disgusting!” 
[b](“ridiculously unnecessary flirting again, seriously?” Check ✓)[/b]
You: “Just shut up and let’s get out of here.”
 [/quote]


Are you feeling it now?

39514110.review:
999 and VLR. Two of the most games I thought I would not have enjoyed...

I was sadly mistaken. 

Normally, I'm not one for puzzle games so I have to admit, when I first heard of anything of the Zero Escape franchise, I was thinking, maybe not. The first time heard was the advertisments for Zero Time Dilemma here and I thought, pfft. Another puzzle game I would not be interested in. When I watched a youtuber play a bit of it, I was then thinking, looks interesting and searched up the franchise. I then found out that after a bit after the release of ZTD, they would then remaster the Nonary games on Steam and PS4. I decided on the whim to get Steams version because they had a sale recently to get the the bundle. Anyways, this isn't the point!

The point is that I normally dislike puzzle escape games, any puzzle games in general really. However, 999 changed that for me. It was fun and creative in how you would escape the rooms. As well as that, there were creative paths for the many different endings. The other thing is this. If you have played Until Dawn, then you will know about the Butterfly Effect (also can be referred to Ripple). Your decisions change the outcome in the games. It was interesting to see that incoporated in the game, and how you would have to alter your decisions to make sure you make the good endings. 

VLR also incorporates it. As well as that, there are more puzzles to go through. However, not goijng to lie. Some of the puzzles in the second game got harder and more challenging, so sometimes I got stressed out and had to take a break, especially when finding the secondary passwords to unlock the "Redacted" achievment. I managed to get through the two games in 52 hours with 100% achievments. I have to admit, it was also quite challenging needing to go back to certain points or finding clues that would unlock other points as you could not continue without certain passwords or whatever. That's about the only thing I didn;t like about the game. The constant returning to areas to look for things you should have noted down, whereas in 999, the things you unlock does not need passwords. 

Despite this, this game has made me slightly interested more in puzzle games. The game can be played in English and Japanese (in my case, I played the game in English with Japanese voices). It was interesting to see some of my favourite voice actors here in a few anime and different games (in this case, the voice actor for Quark was the VA for Alhonse Elric from Full Metal Alchemist, and Zero Junior's voice was done by the VA of Monokuma (can't remember if it was the game or anime though). 

This game is great for both puzzle and anime enthsiasts, and those that like games that involve changing futures with the butterfly effect. 

My personal rating of the game: 10/10, despite the reptitiveness at times.
